POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the history of precipitation change in the Peruvian and Ecuadorian Andes and its influence on natural and human ecologies. The cloud forests of the eastern flank of the Andes is a biodiversity hotspot, rich in endemic species, but poorly studied archaeologically. In this study we analyzed the chemistry of stalagmites from a cave in lowland Ecuador and provided the first high-resolution precipitation record for the region that spanned the last 96,000 years. We were able to establish that major fluctuations in rainfall at centennial to millennial scales were related to changes in the sea-surface temperature of the northern tropical Atlantic Ocean. Shorter-term extremes of precipitation were related to changes in the Pacific Ocean sea-surface temperatures, i.e. cycles of the El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO).

 

We also analyzed the ancient sediments of three Andean lakes for their fossil pollen, diatom, and charcoal contents. The lakes occupied different habitats and revealed contrasting histories of use. Vegetation responses were evident to the millennial-scale (Atlantic Ocean) forcing, but not to the shorter-term (Pacific Ocean) forcing. All lakes showed evidence of cultivation by 5000 years ago, and a change from the dominant cultivation of quinoa to maize at about 3000 years ago. It is not known why this transition occurred, but it may have been in response to warming in the Pacific Ocean and a more active ENSO system. The wettest of the sites showed abandonment of maize cultivation about A.D. 1200 (long before European arrival), and this may reflect the setting becoming too wet.

 

The data generated by this project are directly relevant for understanding the implications of further warming of the oceans and how the knock-on effects that will influence Andean agriculture. Our work is of interest to archaeologists, anthropologists, ecologists, and climatologists. The work has resulted in eight scientific publications, with one in review. These publications have, so far, been cited ~240 times by other researchers.

 

The project supported one Ph.D. student, Nicole Mosblech, who successfully defended her Ph.D. in 2012. Dr. Mosblech is currently employed as a high school biology teacher (was one of five finalists for Florida Teacher of the Year in 2018).  Eight undergraduates received training in laboratory skills and paleoecology as a result of this award.
